Three of the witnesses make the case that Trump could be justifiably impeached for abuse of power, bribery, obstruction of justice and obstruction of Congress. The fourth witness, invited by Republicans on the committee, says thereâ€™s insufficient proof to support a bribery charge and that the process overall has been too rushed.

Dec. 5, 2019: In a public announcement, Pelosi calls on the House Judiciary Committee to proceed with drafting articles of impeachment against Trump, saying "his wrongdoing strikes at the very heart of our Constitution."

Dec. 6, 2019: Cipollone sends a letter to Nadler rejecting the House Judiciary Committeeâ€™s invitation to participate in a Dec. 9 hearing.

Dec. 7, 2019: The House Judiciary Committee releases a 55-page report outlining various historical arguments for impeachment. "Impeachment is the Constitutionâ€™s final answer to a President who mistakes himself for a monarch," the report says.

Dec. 7, 2019: Trump tells reporters that Giuliani is "going to make a report, I think to the attorney general and to Congress," on the basis of a trip he made to Ukraine along with conservative network One America News in early December.

Dec. 9, 2019: The House Judiciary Committee holds a public impeachment hearing on the evidence gathered in the House Intelligence Committeeâ€™s investigation.

Dec. 9, 2019: FBI Director Christopher Wray, in an interview with ABC News, says, "We have no information that indicates that Ukraine interfered with the 2016 presidential election."

Dec. 10, 2019: The House introduces two articles of impeachment against Trump, charging the president with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. (We put them in historical context.)

Dec. 11-12, 2019: The House Judiciary Committee holds a marathon two-day debate to consider the articles of impeachment.

Dec. 12, 2019: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., says on Hannityâ€™s primetime Fox News TV show, "There is no chance the president is going to be removed from office." He says he is "coordinating with White House counsel" at every step.

Dec. 13, 2019: The House Judiciary Committee votes to approve both articles of impeachment, sending both to the full House by party-line votes of 23-17.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., speaks during a vote on the articles of impeachment on Dec. 18, 2019, on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP)

Dec. 16, 2019: The House Judiciary Committee releases a 658-page report outlining the articles of impeachment and arguing that Trumpâ€™s conduct toward Ukraine amounted to "multiple federal crimes." "President Trump has realized the Framersâ€™ worst nightmare," it says.

Dec. 16, 2019: The New Yorker publishes a story in which Giuliani admits that he wanted to get rid of Yovanovitch. "I believed that I needed Yovanovitch out of the way," he says. "She was going to make the investigations difficult for everybody."

Giuliani says he worked with Solomon to broadcast false allegations about Yovanovitch and the Bidens. He also says Lutsenkoâ€™s interview with Bloomberg, in which he denied evidence of wrongdoing by the Bidens, "undermined everything."

Dec. 16, 2019: In an interview with the New York Times, Giuliani says he briefed Trump about Yovanovitch "a couple of times." He says Trump and Pompeo "relied" on his briefings.

Dec. 17, 2019: Trump sends a six-page letter to Pelosi decrying the impeachment process, denying all wrongdoing and repeating many falsehoods about Ukraine and impeachment.

Dec. 18, 2019: Following a dayâ€™s worth of debate on the House floor, the House votes to impeach Trump, approving the abuse of power charge by a 230-197 margin and the obstruction of Congress charge by a vote of 229-198.

Dec. 21, 2019: The Center for Public Integrity publishes documents obtained from the Justice Department showing contacts between the Pentagon and White House about the Ukraine aid.

The documents show that just hours after Trumpâ€™s July 25 call with Zelensky, the OMB told the Pentagon to "hold off" on distributing the funds and keep information of the delay "closely held."

The documents also show that on June 19, Duffey asked the Pentagonâ€™s chief financial officer about the aid, writing, "The President has asked about this funding release."

Jan. 13, 2020: The New York Times reports that Russian hackers targeted Ukrainian subsidiaries of Burisma with phishing campaigns beginning in November.

Jan. 14, 2020: The House Intelligence Committee provides new evidence turned over by Parnas, Giulianiâ€™s Ukrainian business associate, for the House Judiciary Committee to send to the Senate along with the articles of impeachment.

The documents include handwritten notes from Parnas. In one note, Parnas wrote to himself, "Get Zalensky to Annonce that the Biden case will Be Investigated."

The documents also include a May 10, 2019, letter from Giuliani to Zelensky, in which Giuliani expressed his hope that Zelensky would help Ukraine "overcome some of the long-standing problems of the past" and said he had a "more specific request."

"In my capacity as personal counsel to President Trump and with his knowledge and consent, I request a meeting with you on this upcoming Monday, May 13th or Tuesday, May 14th," Giuliani wrote. "I will need no more than a half-hour of your time."

(Giuliani ultimately called off his trip to Ukraine, which he told the New York Times he had planned to use to press Zelensky on the Bidens.)

Other documents include: text messages showing Parnas and Giuliani discussing their attempts to secure a visa for Shokin; text messages showing Parnas and Trump donor Robert Hyde discussing Yovanovitchâ€™s location and recall; text messages showing Parnas and Lutsenko bad-mouthing Yovanovitch; and text messages showing Parnas and several Zelensky aides discussing a meeting between Zelensky and Giuliani and negative information about the Bidens.

Jan. 15, 2020: Pelosi announces the seven Democratic House members who will serve as impeachment managers in the Senate impeachment trial, and the House votes to approve them.

The managers are Reps. Schiff, Nadler, Zoe Lofgren of California, Hakeem Jeffries of New York, Val Demings of Florida, Jason Crow of Colorado and Sylvia Garcia of Texas.

Jan. 15, 2020: The House formally transmits the articles of impeachment to the Senate.

Jan. 15, 2020: In an interview with MSNBCâ€™s Rachel Maddow, Parnas says Trump "knew exactly what was going on" and "was aware of all my movements."

"I wouldnâ€™t do anything without the consent of Rudy Giuliani, or the president," Parnas says. "I was on the ground doing their work."

Parnas says he was often with Giuliani while he was on the phone with Trump. He also implicates Pence, saying the vice presidentâ€™s plan to attend Zelenskyâ€™s inauguration was cancelled because the Ukrainians had not agreed to the desired investigations.

Parnas also says Barr was "basically on the team." And Parnas says he was surprised to see Nunes involved in the Houseâ€™s hearings because he was "involved in getting all this stuff."

"It was all connected," Parnas says. "At the end of the day, the agenda was to make sure that the Ukrainians announced the Biden investigation."

Jan. 16, 2020: The nonpartisan Government Accountability Office concludes that the OMB violated the Impoundment Control Act by withholding security assistance to Ukraine.

"Faithful execution of the law does not permit the President to substitute his own policy priorities for those that Congress has enacted into law," the decision states. "OMB withheld funds for a policy reason, which is not permitted under the Impoundment Control Act."

Jan. 16, 2020: The Internal Affairs Ministry of Ukraine announces that it has opened a criminal investigation into possible unlawful surveillance of Yovanovitch after the texts between Parnas and Hyde featured discussions of her location and use of electronics.

"The published messages contain facts of possible violations of Ukrainian law and of the Vienna Convention on diplomatic relations, which protect the rights of diplomats on the territory of another state," the ministry says.

Jan. 16, 2020: In an interview with CNNâ€™s Anderson Cooper, Parnas reiterates that "everybody that was close to Trump knew that this was a thorn in the side, and this was a serious situation." He describes meeting with a Zelensky aide after Zelensky won his election.

"(Zelensky) needed to immediately make an announcement literally that night or within the next 24 hours that they were opening up an investigation on Biden," Parnas says he told the aide.

"If they didn't make that announcement, basically, there would be no relationship," Parnas says.

Jan. 16, 2020: The Senateâ€™s impeachment proceedings formally begin with the reading of the articles of impeachment and the swearing in of senators and Chief Justice John Roberts.

Jan. 17, 2020: The White House announces Trumpâ€™s legal defense team, led by White House attorneys Cipollone and Jay Sekulow, for the Senate impeachment trial.

The roster includes former independent counsels Ken Starr and Robert Ray, Harvard law professor emeritus Alan Dershowitz, presidential adviser Pam Bondi, private counsel Jane Raskin and attorney Eric Hershmann of the Kasowitz Benson Torres LLP law firm.

Jan. 17, 2020: House Democrats release a second batch of documents turned over by Parnas, which includes a number of photos showing Parnas with Trump, Giuliani and others.

They include more text messages indicating that Yovanovitch may have been under illegal surveillance, such as screenshots of a WhatsApp exchange between Hyde and an unknown Belgian number about Yovanovitch. Hyde sent to the screenshots to Parnas.

The documents also include messages between Parnas and Derek Harvey, an aide to Nunes, in which Parnas helped arrange interviews for Harvey with Ukrainian prosecutors and officials.

Jan. 18, 2020: The House impeachment managers file their legal brief outlining the case for Trumpâ€™s impeachment, arguing that he "used his official powers to pressure a foreign government to interfere in a United States election for his personal political gain, and then attempted to cover up his scheme by obstructing Congressâ€™s investigation."

Jan. 18, 2020: Through his lawyers, Trump files his formal response to the Houseâ€™s brief, writing that the articles of impeachment are "constitutionally invalid" and "a brazen and unlawful attempt to overturn the results of the 2016 election and interfere with the 2020 election."

Jan. 20, 2020: The House managers issue a response denying the allegations laid out in Trumpâ€™s response to their brief.

Jan. 20, 2020: Trumpâ€™s lawyers file their legal brief outlining his defense and calling for the Senate to immediately reject the articles and acquit him. They argue that Trump cannot be impeached because, they say, the House failed to identify a crime or impeachable offense.

Jan. 21, 2020: The House managers file their reply to the Trump teamâ€™s legal brief.

Jan. 21-22, 2020: After nearly 12 hours of debate between House managers and White House attorneys, the Senate votes along party lines to approve rules for a trial.

The rules give the House managers and White House lawyers 24 hours each over the course of three days to make their cases for and against the articles of impeachment. Then, Senators will have 16 hours to ask questions, which will be submitted in writing.

At that point, the Senate will reconsider whether to seek additional evidence from subpoenaed witnesses and documents, according to the New York Times.

Jan. 21, 2020: The Office of Management and Budget releases a trove of heavily-redacted documents related to U.S. aid for Ukraine to ethics watchdog American Oversight in response to a Freedom of Information Act request.

Included are emails between Sandy, Duffey and other OMB and Pentagon officials that show a scramble on July 24 and July 25 to formally freeze the assistance to Ukraine through footnotes in a series of funding documents. The emails indicate that the paperwork to implement the freeze was already in the works prior to Trumpâ€™s phone call with Zelensky.

The documents also show that aides for a number of Republican lawmakers reached out to OMB officials to ask about the freeze before it was publicly reported by Politico.

Jan. 22, 2020: Trump seems to admit that the White House is withholding documents relevant to his trial. "Honestly, we have all the material," he tells reporters in Davos, Switzerland. "They don't have the material."

Jan. 22, 2020: The House managers begin their opening arguments in the Senate trial.

Jan. 23-24, 2020: The House managers continue their arguments in the Senate trial.

Jan. 24, 2020: ABC News reports on the existence of a tape showing Parnas, Fruman and Trump discussing Yovanovitch at a private 2018 donor dinner at Trumpâ€™s Washington hotel.

"Get rid of her," Trump can be heard saying in the tape, which Parnasâ€™ attorney released to the media. "We can get her out tomorrow. I donâ€™t care. Get her out tomorrow. Take her out. OK?"

Jan. 25, 2020: The Trump legal defense team begins its presentation in the Senate trial. (We fact-checked a number of their claims.)

Jan. 26, 2020: The New York Times reports that a draft copy of Boltonâ€™s forthcoming book says Trump told Bolton in August that he wanted to continue withholding aid from Ukraine until the country announced investigations into Biden.

Charles Cooper, Boltonâ€™s attorney, says in a statement that the White House is to blame for disclosing the bookâ€™s contents. He does not deny the New York Times account.

Jan. 27-28, 2020: The Trump legal defense team continues its arguments in the Senate trial. (We fact-checked a number of their claims.)

Jan. 29, 2020: House Foreign Affairs Committee Eliot Engel releases a statement in response to Trumpâ€™s claim on Twitter that Bolton said "nothing" when he left his post. Engel says he spoke to Bolton by phone on Sept. 23.

"On that call, Ambassador Bolton suggested to me â€” unprompted â€” that the committee look into the recall of Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch," Engel says. "He strongly implied that something improper had occurred around her removal as our top diplomat in Kyiv."

Jan. 29-30, 2020: Senators submit questions in writing to the House managers and the Trump legal defense team in two eight-hour sessions. (We answered a handful of their questions.)

Jan. 31, 2020: The Senate votes against a motion to subpoena witnesses and documents. The vote occurs largely along party lines, 51-49, with two Republicans breaking rank.

Jan. 31, 2020: Parnasâ€™ attorney releases another recording showing Parnas and Fruman at a private, April 2018 Trump donor event at Trumpâ€™s Mar-a-Lago estate, per the Washington Post.

Jan. 31, 2020: The New York Times reports that, according to Boltonâ€™s book manuscript, Trump directed Bolton during an Oval Office meeting in early May to call Zelensky and ensure that he would meet with Giuliani during Giulianiâ€™s planned trip to Ukraine that month.

Giuliani and Cipollone were also present for the roughly 10-minute conversation, according to the New York Timesâ€™ report on the book draftâ€™s contents.

Jan. 31, 2020: In a court filing, the Justice Department reveals that it has 24 "emails that reflect communications by either the president, the vice president, or the presidentâ€™s immediate advisors regarding presidential Â­decision-making about the scope, duration, and purpose of the hold on military assistance to Ukraine," according to the Washington Post. The revelation comes as part of a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit brought by the Center for Public Integrity.

Feb. 3-4, 2020: The House managers and Trump legal defense team make closing arguments in the Senate impeachment trial. Senators begin two days of debate.

Feb. 5, 2020: The Senate acquits Trump on both charges. On the abuse of power charge, the vote to acquit is 52-48, with all Democrats, Independents and Sen. Mitt Romney of Utah voting to convict, and all other Republicans voting to acquit.

On the obstruction of Congress charge, the vote to acquit is 53-47, with all Republicans voting to acquit and all Democrats and Independents voting to convict.

RELATED STORY: PolitiFact's Trump-Biden-Ukraine coverage all in one place

Source title: Bulos y desinformaciones sobre el ataque de Rusia contra Ucrania - Maldita.es - Periodismo para que no te la cuelen
title: 207 bulos y desinformaciones sobre el ataque de Rusia contra Ucrania Â· Maldita.es
text:
Desde que comenzÃ³ el ataque de Rusia a Ucrania en febrero de 2022, se difunden en redes decenas de vÃ­deos e imÃ¡genes supuestamente vinculados a la invasiÃ³n, sin embargo muchos de ellos no son actuales ni se han grabado en el paÃ­s del este europeo. Hemos desmentido 207. Recuerda que en situaciones de crisis y ante la duda, es mejor no compartir.

En #UkraineFacts puedes ver en quÃ© paÃ­ses se ha detectado cada desinformaciÃ³n y acceder a los desmentidos de las diferentes organizaciones de verificaciÃ³n que lo han investigado.

Puedes escuchar nuestro podcast especial 'Un aÃ±o de la invasiÃ³n de Ucrania y sus bulos' en Ivoox, Spotify y Apple Podcast

A continuaciÃ³n, recopilamos los bulos y las desinformaciones que hemos desmentido en Maldita.es sobre la invasiÃ³n rusa de Ucrania:

No, este vÃ­deo donde aparece Zelenski arrodillÃ¡ndose ante supuestas autoridades saudÃ­es no es real: estÃ¡ generado con IA

Circula una grabaciÃ³n en la que aparece VlodÃ­mir Zelenski arrodillÃ¡ndose ante supuestas autoridades saudÃ­es vestidas con el traje nacional de Arabia SaudÃ­. Es un bulo: se trata de un vÃ­deo generado con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial llamada Hailuo AI.

QuÃ© sabemos del supuesto anuncio para niÃ±os del Servicio de Seguridad de Ucrania animando a denunciar a familiares que estÃ©n a favor de Rusia

Circula un vÃ­deo en las redes sociales con mensajes que dicen que un canal infantil ucraniano ha puesto un anuncio del Servicio de Seguridad de Ucrania que anima a denunciar a sus familiares si consumen contenidos rusos o estÃ¡n a favor de Rusia. El canal de televisiÃ³n Plus Plus, cuyo logo aparece en el clip, ha dicho en que es un â€œvÃ­deo falsoâ€ que no se ha emitido, que el logo no es el mismo que el que tiene la cadena actualmente y que cuando emiten anuncios no ponen un QR. A 13 de marzo de 2025 no hay rastro de una campaÃ±a similar del Servicio de Seguridad de Ucrania.

No, The Wall Street Journal no ha publicado que Ucrania "pagÃ³" la Ãºltima "visita y estancia de su delegaciÃ³n en Estados Unidos"

Circula un contenido en inglÃ©s que muestra una supuesta captura de una noticia de The Wall Street Journal que dice Ucrania ha pagado en su Ãºltima visita a Estados Unidos la estancia de su delegaciÃ³n, ya que la administraciÃ³n de Trump se negÃ³ a hacerlo. Es un bulo: a 3 de marzo de 2025 no hay pruebas de que The Wall Street Journal haya publicado nada similar y tampoco lo recogen otras publicaciones. El contenido imita una publicaciÃ³n del periÃ³dico estadounidense.

No, Macron no se equivocÃ³ al seÃ±alar a Ucrania en el mapa de este vÃ­deo: estÃ¡ manipulado

â€œEl presidente Macron muestra y seÃ±ala con orgullo pedagÃ³gico un mapa de Ucrania del revÃ©s, donde el DonbÃ¡s aparece en el oeste, el lugar de en el este. No sabe ni dÃ³nde estÃ¡ Ucrania, ni lo que esâ€. Este es uno de los mensajes con lo que se difunde un vÃ­deo en el que se ve y escucha cÃ³mo el presidente de Francia, Emmanuel Macron dice el â€œeste de Ucraniaâ€ y seÃ±ala hacia el oeste. Pero es un bulo. El vÃ­deo original muestra a Macron seÃ±alando hacia el lado correcto del mapa, sin embargo, se aprecia el mapa al revÃ©s por una cuestiÃ³n de efecto espejo al momento de la grabaciÃ³n. Los vÃ­deos que circulan fueron manipulados para hacer parecer que el presidente francÃ©s seÃ±ala el lado incorrecto del mapa.

No, en este vÃ­deo no aparece Zelenski bailando: es un bailarÃ­n argentino



Circula un vÃ­deo donde supuestamente aparece Zelenski bailando con un vestido ajustado con brillantes. Es un bulo: el vÃ­deo muestra a un bailarÃ­n profesional de Argentina llamado Pablo Acosta, quien subiÃ³ directamente el vÃ­deo a sus redes sociales en 2023.

Cuidado con este vÃ­deo donde parece que Zelenski habla en 2019 de invadir el DonbÃ¡s: el vÃ­deo estÃ¡ recortado

â€œLucharemos, nuestro ejÃ©rcito estÃ¡ listo, iremos al DonbÃ¡s con la guerra, tomaremos nuestros territorios con la guerra y la fuerza militar y no nos importa cuÃ¡ntas personas mueranâ€, dice VolodÃ­mir Zelenski, presidente de Ucrania, en un vÃ­deo que se difunde afirmando que planeaba invadir el DonbÃ¡s desde 2019. Es una desinformaciÃ³n. Se trata de un vÃ­deo recortado, en el original empieza la frase hablando de lo que la sociedad no quiere y sobre un acuerdo de paz. El montaje de las imÃ¡genes fue elaborado a partir de fragmentos del maratÃ³n de 14 horas de Zelenski con los medios de comunicaciÃ³n el 10 de octubre de 2019.

El bulo de que Zelenski no se reuniÃ³ con el secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos en Kiev porque estaba durmiendo

Donald Trump dijo que el presidente de Ucrania VolodÃ­mir Zelenski â€œse quedÃ³ dormido y no estaba disponibleâ€ para una reuniÃ³n con Scott Bessent, secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos. Pero es un bulo que Zelenski se quedase dormido y no se reuniese con Bessent, como afirmÃ³ Trump. Diferentes medios han publicado imÃ¡genes y vÃ­deos en los que se ve a Zelenski y Bessent en la reuniÃ³n acordada en Kiev el 12 de febrero de 2025.

"Ucrania vende las armas que le envÃ­a EEUU a los cÃ¡rteles mexicanos": se difunde sin pruebas y el origen es un vÃ­deo de 2023 que no dice eso



Circula un vÃ­deo del expresentador de Fox News Tucker Carlson, donde dice que el ejÃ©rcito de Ucrania estÃ¡ vendiendo las armas que Estados Unidos les envÃ­a para luchar en la guerra contra Rusia al mercado negro y terminan en cÃ¡rteles mexicanos de droga. Carlson hace esta afirmaciÃ³n sin dar ningÃºn tipo de prueba y se trata de una narrativa que circula desde 2023, cuando se viralizÃ³ el vÃ­deo de un informativo de MÃ©xico donde aparecÃ­a un narco con un tipo lanzagranadas que se estaba â€œutilizando en la invasiÃ³n a Ucraniaâ€, pero en ningÃºn momento se decÃ­a que ese fuese el origen de ese en concreto. SegÃºn varios estudios, investigaciones o literatura sobre el tema, las armas que usan los cÃ¡rteles mexicanos son en su mayorÃ­a del mercado negro estadounidense y del contrabando que se hace en esta frontera.

No, Fox News no ha publicado que el "Centro de Guerra PsicolÃ³gica y de la InformaciÃ³n" de Ucrania recibiÃ³ 140 millones de dÃ³lares mensuales de USAID

Lo que circula: una captura de pantalla que atribuye a Fox News una publicaciÃ³n sobre que el â€œCentro de Guerra PsicolÃ³gica y de la InformaciÃ³n de Ucraniaâ€ recibiÃ³ 140 millones de dÃ³lares mensuales de USAID (la Agencia de Estados Unidos para el Desarrollo Internacional). La publicaciÃ³n supuestamente se hizo con fecha del 10 de febrero de 2025 a las 3:54 horas.

VerificaciÃ³n: es un bulo. Se trata de una imagen manipulada en la que han cambiado el titular de un contenido que Fox News publicÃ³ en esa misma fecha y hora y que no menciona los supuestos cobros.

La desinformaciÃ³n sobre Ben Stiller y su visita pagada a Ucrania: 16 millones de visualizaciones y mÃ¡s de 181 horas sin nota de la comunidad en Twitter (X)*

Un tuit viral desinformador que acusa a Ben Stiller, actor y comediante estadounidense, de recibir cuatro millones de dÃ³lares de USAID por sacarse fotos con el presidente ucraniano VolodimÃ­r Zelenski, acumula 16,2 millones de visualizaciones en Twitter (ahora X). A pesar de que el contenido proviene de una desinformaciÃ³n y de que (a las 12:02 horas del 13 de febrero de 2025) han pasado 181 horas desde su publicaciÃ³n, el tuit no tiene ninguna nota de la comunidad visible (el sistema que permite a usuarios agregar contexto a tuits engaÃ±osos). SÃ­ hay notas propuestas que no se muestran por falta de consenso entre colaboradores con â€œdiferentes puntos de vistaâ€.

En Maldita.es hemos identificado que el tiempo que se tarda en mostrar las notas y la necesidad de consenso entre usuarios que suelen estar en desacuerdo son algunos de los puntos a mejorar del sistema de Notas de Comunidad de X, que Meta planea imitar e implementar en Instagram, Facebook y Threads en reemplazo al sistema de verificaciÃ³n externo. Estos problemas pueden provocar que notas con informaciÃ³n fiable sobre temas polarizantes nunca se muestren o que lleguen demasiado tarde para reducir de forma efectiva la desinformaciÃ³n.

Estrellas de Hollywood en Ucrania supuestamente pagadas por USAID: una campaÃ±a de desinformaciÃ³n vinculada al Kremlin y la ineficacia de las Notas de la Comunidad de Twitter

El vÃ­deo que dice que la Agencia Internacional para el Desarrollo de Estados Unidos (USAID) ha pagado las visitas de varias personas reconocidas de Estados Unidos a Ucrania se ha viralizado con mensajes (falsos) en, al menos, nueve idiomas diferentes (alemÃ¡n, espaÃ±ol, francÃ©s, inglÃ©s, neerlandÃ©s, italiano, polaco, portuguÃ©s y rumano). AsÃ­, su impacto ha traspasado fronteras, llegando a sumar mÃ¡s de 20 millones de reproducciones en Twitter (ahora X) en tan solo tres dÃ­as.

Para este estudio, Maldita.es ha analizado mÃ¡s de 40 publicaciones (todas ellas con mÃ¡s de 5.000 visualizaciones a las 17 horas del 7 de febrero de 2025) que difunden este vÃ­deo con mensajes desinformadores a travÃ©s de X. Estos contenidos han sido publicados a lo largo de tres dÃ­as (entre el 5 y el 7 de febrero) y, en su conjunto, suman millones de reproducciones en la plataforma. AÃºn asÃ­, Ãºnicamente el 14,3% (es decir, seis de 42) cuentan con notas de comunidad que advierten a los usuarios de que es contenido desinformador.

Los supuestos 30.000 soldados franceses muertos en Ucrania: el Ministerio de las Fuerzas Armadas francÃ©s asegura que "es falso" y lo difunden webs y canales de Telegram rusos

text:
BrasÃ£o das ForÃ§as de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais das ForÃ§as Armadas da UcrÃ¢nia, com o lema â€œEu vou atÃ© vocÃª!â€ (Em ucraniano: Ğ†Ğ´Ñƒ Ğ½Ğ° Ğ²Ğ¸!).

Estado-Maior das ForÃ§as Armadas da UcrÃ¢nia;

Comando das ForÃ§as Conjuntas das ForÃ§as Armadas da UcrÃ¢nia;

As ForÃ§as Singulares: ForÃ§a Terrestre, ForÃ§a AÃ©rea e Marinha de Guerra;

As ForÃ§as Conjuntas (organizadas de forma permanente): ForÃ§a de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais; ForÃ§a de Sistemas NÃ£o-Tripulados; ForÃ§as de Defesa Territorial; ForÃ§a de LogÃ­stica; ForÃ§a de Apoio (PolÃ­cia Militar, Bandas Militares, Unidades de Cerimonial e outras); ForÃ§a MÃ©dicas; Tropas de Assalto AÃ©reo (Paraquedistas e AeromÃ³veis); Tropas de ComunicaÃ§Ãµes EstratÃ©gicas e SeguranÃ§a CibernÃ©tica.



As forÃ§as mais jovens sÃ£o justamente a ForÃ§a de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais (FOE), criada em 2016, e a ForÃ§a de Sistemas NÃ£o-Tripulados, criada em 2024.

No artigo A forÃ§a de sistemas nÃ£o-pilotados da UcrÃ¢nia e o exÃ©rcito do futuro , publicado no Velho General, jÃ¡ havÃ­amos tido a oportunidade de tratar da ForÃ§a de Sistemas NÃ£o-Tripulados. No presente artigo, trataremos da ForÃ§a de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais da UcrÃ¢nia, uma tropa pouco conhecida no Brasil, mas que vem sendo empregada extensivamente na Guerra Russo-Ucraniana.

Desde a invasÃ£o russa de 2022, as ForÃ§as de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais (FOE) da UcrÃ¢nia vÃªm sendo empregadas em vÃ¡rias de suas capacidades, sejam elas convencionais, nÃ£o-convencionais (irregulares) ou em apoio Ã s operaÃ§Ãµes de informaÃ§Ã£o. O modelo adotado procurou seguir um padrÃ£o OTAN, mas com algumas diferenÃ§as resultantes da cultura militar soviÃ©tica, que ainda influencia a doutrina ucraniana.

A FOE tem desfrutado de vÃ¡rios sucessos, no entanto, existem deficiÃªncias sistÃªmicas que reduzem sua eficÃ¡cia. Procuraremos explorar os aspectos conhecidos da FOE ucraniana.

A origem das FOE ucranianas, remontando ao modelo soviÃ©tico, se deu a partir das tropas Spetsnaz (abreviatura de â€œspetsialnogo naznacheniyaâ€, cuja traduÃ§Ã£o seria â€œpropÃ³sito especialâ€). As tropas Spetsnaz eram vinculadas Ã  Diretoria Principal de InteligÃªncia (GUR) do MinistÃ©rio da Defesa da UcrÃ¢nia e ficaram assim atÃ© quando grupos de forÃ§as especiais ucranianas passaram a ser treinados no modelo das forÃ§as de operaÃ§Ãµes especiais da OTAN.

ApÃ³s insucessos na Guerra do Donbass, a partir de 2014, sentiu-se a necessidade da criaÃ§Ã£o de um comando das forÃ§as especiais. Isso se deu em 2016, quando as FOE passaram a constituir um ramo unificado, caracterÃ­stica bastante marcante do modelo soviÃ©tico, que prioriza o emprego conjunto desde o tempo de paz.

As FOE ficam diretamente subordinadas ao Comando das ForÃ§as de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais da UcrÃ¢nia (UKRSOCOM), que Ã© seu prÃ³prio comando dentro da estrutura organizacional da ForÃ§as Armadas ucranianas (MINISTÃ‰RIO DA DEFESA DA UCRÃ‚NIA, 2025).

Antes da reforma de 2016, as tropas de operaÃ§Ãµes especiais ficavam diretamente subordinadas aos comandos militares regionais conjuntos. AlÃ©m disso, a UcrÃ¢nia mantinha grupos de operaÃ§Ãµes especiais dentro da Diretoria Principal de inteligÃªncia (GUR). A criaÃ§Ã£o do UKRSOCOM representou uma centralizaÃ§Ã£o de meios para o preparo, adestramento e administraÃ§Ã£o. No emprego, as FOE ucranianas sÃ£o frequentemente adjudicadas aos comandantes operacionais no Ã¢mbito de um Teatro de Guerra.

Em junho de 2019, o 140Âº Centro de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais da FOE ucraniana foi certificado como uma unidade de operaÃ§Ãµes especiais capacitada a integrar uma ForÃ§a de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais da OTAN, sendo a primeira de um estado nÃ£o membro da alianÃ§a a obter esse status (UNIAN, 2019).

Em 1Âº de janeiro de 2022, o efetivo da FOE aumentou em 1.000 homens (UKRAINSKA PRAVDA, 2022), com a seguinte organizaÃ§Ã£o:

Comando-Geral das ForÃ§as de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais;

Unidades de Combate para PropÃ³sitos Especiais (Terra);

Unidade de Combate para PropÃ³sitos Especiais (Fuzileiros Navais);

Unidade de Combate para PropÃ³sitos Especiais (AviaÃ§Ã£o);

Unidades de combate terrestre (Comandos);

Doutrina

As tarefas da FOE incluem as seguintes capacidades (MINISTÃ‰RIO DA DEFESA DA UCRÃ‚NIA, 2025):

Participar de ataques atrÃ¡s das linhas inimigas;

Coletar inteligÃªncia;

Realizar aÃ§Ãµes de espionagem;

O centro de treinamento das ForÃ§as de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais estÃ¡ sediado em Khmelnitsky e Ã© lÃ¡ que os recrutas candidatos passam pelo Centro de QualificaÃ§Ã£o da FOE. O curso de seleÃ§Ã£o Ã© financiado pelos Estados Unidos, e foi desenvolvido em parceria com outros paÃ­ses da OTAN, particularmente a LetÃ´nia, a LituÃ¢nia e a EstÃ´nia.

A doutrina de emprego das FOE ucranianas busca se fundamentar nos modelos ocidentais desde 2015.

Suas principais missÃµes sÃ£o:

AÃ§Ãµes diretas: Este constitui o que seria o papel mais visÃ­vel do UKRSOCOM, onde as forÃ§as de OperaÃ§Ãµes Especiais participam de uma ampla variedade de operaÃ§Ãµes de aÃ§Ãµes contra a RÃºssia. Equipes da FOE sÃ£o preparadas para realizar operaÃ§Ãµes de infiltraÃ§Ã£o, nas quais os operadores penetrarÃ£o profundamente atrÃ¡s das linhas inimigas e destruirÃ£o objetivos militares ou infraestruturas inimigas. Um exemplo notÃ¡vel disso foi uma infiltraÃ§Ã£o naval para destruir unidades de radar de defesa aÃ©rea russas na Crimeia, facilitando ataques com mÃ­sseis contra o porto de Sebastopol em agosto de 2023.

Mais recentemente, forÃ§as de operaÃ§Ãµes especiais se infiltraram preliminarmente na regiÃ£o russa de Kursk, destruindo infraestruturas-chave e capturando unidades russas maiores antes da invasÃ£o convencional da UcrÃ¢nia em agosto de 2024.

HÃ¡ relatos de que operaÃ§Ãµes de aÃ§Ã£o direta tambÃ©m foram realizadas pela FOE ucraniana na SÃ­ria e no SudÃ£o, combatendo tropas russas ou elementos do Grupo Wagner fora do Teatro de Guerra na UcrÃ¢nia. Em novembro de 2024, uma aÃ§Ã£o sobre tropas russas perto de Aleppo teria sido desencadeada por elementos da FOE ucraniana, apoiando rebeldes sÃ­rios (MALYASOV, 2024).

Entretanto, devido Ã  falta de efetivos e unidades convencionais, as forÃ§as do UKRSOCOM vÃªm cada vez mais participando de aÃ§Ãµes convencionais contra a RÃºssia, lutando nas linhas de frente, como Ã© o caso em Kursk, onde as unidades que realizaram a infiltraÃ§Ã£o inicial permanecem combatendo na linha de frente atÃ© o dia de hoje, sem terem sido exfiltradas, o que seria normal. As forÃ§as de operaÃ§Ãµes especiais, quando empregadas como tropa de infantaria, acabam perdendo seus conjuntos de habilidades mais amplos, tem menor apoio de fogo e acabam sofrendo baixas significativas.

AÃ§Ãµes NÃ£o-Convencionais: O UKRSOCOM tem capacidade de treinar, incorporar e apoiar materialmente a ampla gama de cÃ©lulas de resistÃªncia civil que permanecem no territÃ³rio ocupado pela RÃºssia. As unidades da FOE buscam explorar o potencial de inteligÃªncia dos ucranianos que vivem atrÃ¡s das linhas russas para atuar com mais eficÃ¡cia.

O modus operandi dessas aÃ§Ãµes Ã© normalmente a execuÃ§Ã£o de sabotagens empregando civis locais, cujos alvos sÃ£o, normalmente, a infraestrutura crÃ­tica russa, incluindo as militares, figuras polÃ­ticas e depÃ³sitos de material. AlÃ©m disso, os elementos das FOE ucranianas, incorporados Ã  resistÃªncia civil tambÃ©m realizam assassinatos de tropas e oficiais russos, bem como operaÃ§Ãµes de guerra de informaÃ§Ã£o para intimidar as forÃ§as de ocupaÃ§Ã£o e seus colaboradores.

A capacidade do UKRSOCOM de conduzir essas operaÃ§Ãµes foi significativamente melhorada por um projeto de lei de 2021 que permite o treinamento, armamento e pagamento de civis para aÃ§Ãµes de resistÃªncia contra tropas ocupantes durante a guerra.

Fora do Teatro de OperaÃ§Ãµes da UcrÃ¢nia, as FOE Ucranianas atuam ao lado das forÃ§as rebeldes do Mali e da SÃ­ria para interromper os esforÃ§os russos na regiÃ£o. Na SÃ­ria, por exemplo, as forÃ§as ucranianas do HUR trabalharam ao lado de grupos rebeldes para atingir instalaÃ§Ãµes e pessoal russos. A UcrÃ¢nia tambÃ©m contribuiu para os esforÃ§os mÃ©dicos com grupos rebeldes sÃ­rios. No Mali, por exemplo, uma emboscada que levou Ã  morte de 84 soldados Wagner foi possibilitada pela inteligÃªncia ucraniana e pelo treinamento de drones (LISTER et al., 2024).

Essas aÃ§Ãµes nÃ£o ocorreram sem desvantagens, principalmente no caso do Mali, onde a naÃ§Ã£o rompeu laÃ§os diplomÃ¡ticos com a UcrÃ¢nia em resposta Ã  sua cooperaÃ§Ã£o com grupos rebeldes.

Um dos esforÃ§os principais da FOE ucraniana em 2024 foi organizar movimentos de resistÃªncia nas Ã¡reas de Donetsk e Lughansk ocupadas pela RÃºssia. De acordo com a doutrina ucraniana, a organizaÃ§Ã£o de um movimento de resistÃªncia envolve a criaÃ§Ã£o de:

ForÃ§as de resistÃªncia;

Equipes de elementos de resistÃªncia subterrÃ¢nea;

ForÃ§as auxiliares especializadas (apoio).

Estruturar todas essas equipes em territÃ³rios controlados pelos russos nÃ£o tem sido uma tarefa simples e demanda tempo, mas jÃ¡ se observam alguns resultados. Por exemplo, em janeiro de 2024, o movimento de resistÃªncia organizado pela FOE na RÃºssia incendiou vÃ¡rias instalaÃ§Ãµes ferroviÃ¡rias, que sÃ£o usadas para a logÃ­stica das ForÃ§as Armadas russas.

OperaÃ§Ãµes de InformaÃ§Ã£o: uma contribuiÃ§Ã£o fundamental para as operaÃ§Ãµes de informaÃ§Ã£o por parte das FOE ucranianas Ã© a preparaÃ§Ã£o e divulgaÃ§Ã£o de imagens bem-sucedidas da linha de frente, realizadas massivamente por meio das redes sociais.

As imagens obtidas em cÃ¢meras nos capacetes e em drones fornecem confirmaÃ§Ãµes visuais de sucessos ucranianos contra as forÃ§as russas, e com isso, contribuem para aumenta o moral da populaÃ§Ã£o e a percepÃ§Ã£o de sucesso das aÃ§Ãµes militares ucranianas para a opiniÃ£o pÃºblica global e para as lideranÃ§as de seus aliados.

Esses grupos normalmente participam das atividades de aÃ§Ã£o direta, bem como de outras atividades da FOE. Para as operaÃ§Ãµes de informaÃ§Ã£o, a FOE possui a seguinte estrutura em termos de unidades, o que revela a importÃ¢ncia dessa capacidade (MOMI, 2024):

16Âº Centro de OperaÃ§Ãµes de InformaÃ§Ã£o e OperaÃ§Ãµes PsicolÃ³gicas, com sede em Huiva, regiÃ£o de Zhytomyr;

72Âº Centro de OperaÃ§Ãµes de InformaÃ§Ã£o e OperaÃ§Ãµes PsicolÃ³gicas, com sede em Brovary, regiÃ£o de Kiev;

74Âº Centro de OperaÃ§Ãµes de InformaÃ§Ã£o e OperaÃ§Ãµes PsicolÃ³gicas, com sede em Lvov;

83Âº Centro de OperaÃ§Ãµes de InformaÃ§Ã£o e OperaÃ§Ãµes PsicolÃ³gicas, com sede em Odessa.

LiÃ§Ãµes aprendidas e interferÃªncia polÃ­tica

Embora haja muitos sucessos registrados no emprego das FOE ucranianas, tambÃ©m existem deficiÃªncias importantes. Na prÃ¡tica, o que se observa Ã© que o UKRSOCOM acaba atuando de maneira muito semelhante ao que era realizada antes de 2016. Como temos visto em Kursk e em outras frentes, as forÃ§as de operaÃ§Ãµes especiais adjudicadas aos comandantes convencionais acabam tendo seu emprego desvirtuado devido Ã  falta de pessoal.

O fato Ã© que os comandantes muitas vezes ignoram a melhor forma de empregar essas forÃ§as, em grande parte, devido Ã  prÃ³pria carÃªncia de oficiais de Estado-Maior bem formados, assim como a falta de treinamento e exercÃ­cios entre comandos. O que se observa Ã© que o adestramento conjunto, particularmente incluindo elementos do UKRSOCOM, raramente sÃ£o realizados.

Consequentemente, essas tropas altamente nobres sÃ£o frequentemente empregadas como elementos de infantaria, apenas se diferenciando por utilizar tÃ¡ticas mais agressivas e de alta intensidade.

As estimativas de completamento das unidades da linha de frente ucranianas costumam ficar em torno de 35%, e muitas tÃªm claros ainda maiores. Isso oferece uma explicaÃ§Ã£o sobre porque os comandantes convencionais estÃ£o empregando suas equipes FOE nessas capacidades convencionais, devido Ã  escassez de mÃ£o de obra, alÃ©m de ilustrar que as SOF provavelmente tambÃ©m estÃ£o sofrendo altas baixas nessas funÃ§Ãµes.

As taxas de baixas (feridos graves e mortos) para as FOE ucranianas sÃ£o bem mais sigilosas do que a das demais tropas ucranianas, mas se estima que elas estejam ocorrendo num ritmo cada vez mais elevado. Como as SOF jÃ¡ sÃ£o uma forÃ§a muito menor que requer muito mais tempo e recursos para treinar do que um soldado de infantaria padrÃ£o, seu uso nessa funÃ§Ã£o Ã© um uso profundamente ineficiente dessa capacidade.

O que se observa, entretanto, Ã© que este tipo de emprego tem sido explorado intensamente pela guerra informacional russa.

Gardener et al. (2024) relatou o caso de uma matÃ©ria publicada no Financial Times (do Reino Unido) onde uma fonte ucraniana anÃ´nima â€œreclamou que sua unidade de forÃ§as especiais agora estava sendo forÃ§ada a lutar como infantaria regularâ€. O serviÃ§o de notÃ­cias estatal russo, RIA Novosti, citou o artigo como evidÃªncia de que as forÃ§as ucranianas estavam em apuros, o que nÃ£o deixa de ser uma verdade. Essa mensagem foi entÃ£o amplificada nas comunidades de analistas militares nas mÃ­dias sociais, que passaram a divulgar que as FOE ucranianas estavam sendo empregadas para â€œtapar buracosâ€ nas fileiras do ExÃ©rcito ucraniano.

Mas o fato Ã© que, Ã  medida em que o conflito continua, a decisÃ£o ucraniana de usar as FOE como tropas de assalto terÃ£o que levar em conta nÃ£o apenas os custos e riscos imediatos de tais operaÃ§Ãµes, mas tambÃ©m as consequÃªncias de longo prazo, como a forma como serÃ£o percebidas pelos prÃ³prios soldados, pelo pÃºblico e pelos observadores internacionais.

Segundo Kremzner (2025), outro problema sÃ©rio verificado no emprego das FOE ucranianas tem sido a decisÃ£o pelo seu uso na SÃ­ria e na Ãfrica. Buscando o objetivo polÃ­tico de obter vitÃ³rias na guerra informacional, o emprego das FOE seria muito mais efetivo se fosse concentrado no teatro de operaÃ§Ãµes ucraniano, e certamente revela uma interferÃªncia polÃ­tica, provavelmente do prÃ³prio presidente Zelensky.

Source title: Saakashvili arrested in Kyiv, deported to Poland (VIDEO)
title: Saakashvili arrested in Kyiv, deported to Poland (VIDEO)
text:
Former Odesa Oblast Governor and ex-Georgian President Mikheil Saakashvili has been deported to Poland, a State Border Service spokesman said on the evening of Feb. 12.

Saakashvili was arrested in a downtown Kyiv restaurant earlier in the day, with footage of the arrest quickly circulating on the internet.

JOIN US ON TELEGRAM Follow our coverage of the war on the @Kyivpost_official.

Video footage from the cafe shows Saakashvili being brutally brought out of the cafe by armed men and taken by the hair. Saakashviliâ€™s press office said the armed men had hit him in the face, threatened to shoot at him and put him down on the floor of a bus.

could be interesting for you: Russia's Allies â€“ Where Do They Stand?

Saakashvili is arrested in a Kyiv cafe on Feb. 12.

Saakashviliâ€™s deportation comes after a series of Ukrainian court rulings against the former governor, who was stripped of his Ukrainian citizenship last year after a falling out with President Petro Poroshenko.

Advertisement

State Border Service spokesman Oleh Slobodyan confirmed on his Facebook page that Saakashvili was arrested by the agencyâ€™s officers, the State Migration Service and regular police officers. He said Saakashvili was sent â€œto the country from which he came,â€ likely a reference to the Georgian politicianâ€™s September 2017 crossing of the Ukrainian border with Poland.

Slobodyan added that Saakashvili was deported because the Ukrainian courts refused to grant him refugee status.

It was not immediately clear when the 50-year-old former Georgian president left Ukraine.

In the immediate aftermath of his arrest, Saakashviliâ€™s political party issued a statement claiming that â€œunknown persons in masks have captured and taken Mikheil Saakashvili to an unknown location.â€

A Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) spokeswoman denied that the SBU was involved in Saakashviliâ€™s detention. A spokeswoman for the General Prosecutorâ€™s Office said that â€œtodayâ€™s events relating to Saakashvili are outside the purview of the General Prosecutor of Ukraine.â€

Advertisement

The men who arrested Saakashvili had the insignia of State Border Service, Vladimir Fedorin, Saakashviliâ€™s ally, who was present at the spot of the arrest, told the Kyiv Post.

Saakashvili supporters fear he might be deported from Ukraine later the day. Some of them have already headed to block Kyiv airports, a source in Saakashviliâ€™s party told the Kyiv Post.

Reuters reported that the â€œkidnappersâ€ traveled in â€œthree white minivans.â€

Ukrainian media agencies reported earlier that Saakashvili could be sent to Poland or the Netherlands. Dutch Foreign Minister Halbe Zijlstra said in December 2017 that the Netherlands had approved a request to provide Saakashvili with a visa.

â€œHe is married to a Dutch woman and if he applies for a passport it is possible under Dutch law,â€ Zijlstra said. His wife is Sandra Elisabeth Roelofsâ€“Saakashvili. The Dutch Embassy in Kyiv declined to comment.

At 6:12 Kyiv time Saakashviliâ€™s ally David Sakvarelidze posted on his Facebook that he had received a phone call from Saakashvili from Warsaw.

Saakashvili said that Poland had only agreed to accept him if he arrived voluntarily but he had told Polish authorities he had been brought to the country by force, and violence had been used against him.

Advertisement

The Kyiv Administrative Court of Appeal on Feb. 5 rejected Saakashviliâ€™s political asylum appeal, potentially opening a way for his deportation or extradition from Ukraine.

Saakashviliâ€™s lawyers have argued that their client could not be legally deported or extradited regardless of his asylum status, since it is unlawful to deport or extradite permanent stateless residents of Ukraine. Saakashvili also could not be extradited or deported under the law because he was under investigation in a criminal case in Ukraine, they said.

Forced deportation or extradition is only possible under Ukrainian law if there is a specific court warrant for deportation or extradition. Even in that case, such a ruling can be appealed against within 30 days, and extradition or deportation can only happen after the appeals court has made its ruling.

There has been no court ruling on Saakashviliâ€™s deportation, however, despite the fact that forced deportation without a court warrant is banned by the law.

Saakashviliâ€™s deportation or extradition would also be illegal during the next appeal stage because his lawyers have filed an appeal against the Feb. 5 ruling on asylum with the Supreme Court and because his current residence permit from the State Migration Service is valid until March 1, Saakashviliâ€™s lawyer Ruslan Chernolutsky said on Feb. 6.

Advertisement

Saakashvili and his supporters also argued that he could not be expelled from the country because the cancellation of his Ukrainian citizenship by Poroshenko in July contradicted Ukrainian and international law, the Constitution and due process. His lawyers said that his extradition or deportation was impossible before a court decided on the legality of the cancellation of his citizenship.

In October and November, seven Georgian associates of Saakashvili were deported to Georgia by Ukrainian authorities without court warrants, with the Georgians claiming they had been kidnapped and beaten.

Human Rights Ombudsman Valeria Lutkovska said in November that three of the Georgians had been illegally kidnapped and deported by the National Police without court warrants. The authorities denied accusations of wrongdoing, but failed to present the legal grounds for the deportations.

Read the background story here

Staff writers Oksana Grytsenko and Yuliana Romanyshyn contributed to this report.

Footage from ex-Georgian President Mikheil Saakashviliâ€™s Facebook page shows police officers arresting him at Suluguni restaurant in Kyiv at 10 Myzeiny Alley. Ukrainian authorities are seeking to deport him to Georgia after he became a critic of President Petro Poroshenko after leaving office as Odesa Oblastâ€™s governor in November 2016.
